summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding juror selection. It lists prospective jurors who should proceed to voir dire, those who should be excused by agreement, and those where the defense and government have objections.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell case, addressed in the letter regarding juror selection.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)).

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the joint letter.

connections.description: Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Juror Questionnaires Completed
events.description: Prospective jurors completed questionnaires as part of the jury selection process for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The document is a joint filing from November 13, 2021, in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
The prosecution and defense agreed on a list of prospective jurors to proceed to voir dire and another list to be excused.
The defense and government each listed prospective jurors they individually objected to, indicating disagreements in the jury selection process.
The document shows the trial preparation phase was active in November 2021, focusing on jury selection before Judge Alison J. Nathan.
